elements.text: . We looked at the title and saw the letters
Show the Alphabet Cards for letters
. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat.
makes the /e/ sound you hear in the word
makes the /e/ sound you hear in
Show the Alphabet Cards for the letters
Say the letter aloud and have children repeat.
makes the /f/ sound you hear in the word
makes the /f/ sound you hear in
Today we will read a book about the letters
with the following prompt. Help children notice words with the /e/ in the middle.
Put up one finger when you hear a word that begins with the /e/ sound.
Put up two fingers when you hear a word that begins with the /f/ sound.
Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters
Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters.
, stop at each word that begins with the letter
and any words with medial /e/.  Have children say /e/ and the word with that sound. Repeat with
. Some children will benefit from tracing letters in salt or sand before writing.
To challenge children after reading each story, ask them to combine several of the target words and use them in sentences. Silly sentences are even more fun. For example, you might say
Fox put a feather in his hat!
Take extra time as needed, to review the sounds the letters in
make in isolation and in the context of a picture word.

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form each letter sound, being mindful of your lip positions. Do this while saying the sound in isolation and again as you say the sound within the picture word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as they make the letter sound.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Three plastic hoops or buckets, masking tape, beanbags
We saw how Ceci and her grandma worked hard to build an ofrenda. They persisted until they finally had a beautiful ofrenda for everyone to enjoy.
When you keep working on something, even if it’s hard to do or because your teacher asked you to do it, you are persisting.
Today, we’re going to show how important it is to persist and try hard.
I’m going to place this hoop on the floor. I’m going to toss a beanbag and see if I can make the beanbag land inside the hoop.
I am going to keep trying until I get it in.
Assign partners. For each pair, set out a hoop and provide beanbags. Place a line on the floor with masking tape and tell children to stay behind the line when they toss the beanbag.
Have partners take turns tossing the beanbags until both children have tossed the beanbags into the hoop.
Move the hoops so the task becomes more difficult and have the children continue the activity.
Ask children what happened when they tried to get the beanbag into the hoop. Encourage them to tell about how they persisted and how they felt when they succeeded.

Some children will find it easier to keep working on something they want to do. Giving children a choice about where to place the hoop might help encourage their persistence. You don’t want children to become frustrated, so move the hoop closer if needed.
For children who enjoy a challenge, set the number of tosses before they begin to play. Then gradually increase the number of tosses that equal success.
To help children talk about their experience in persisting, ask questions similar to these:
Was it hard for you to keep trying? When did you think you wanted to stop? What made you continue to try?
Make sure the task is appropriate to the abilities of the child. Tailor this activity for children who may have difficulty with the kind of coordination needed for this activity.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
A three-page booklet for each child
and talked about what the author of the book did and what the illustrator did. We looked at picture clues that the illustrator showed us to help us better understand the story.
Now, we’re going to be illustrators.
I am going to give you a three-page storybook. There will be one word on each page of your book.
You are going to make a picture to go with the story. Remember your picture will help tell the story.
Show children how you make a book about the park. Write a word on each page—
My story is about a boy, a kite, and a dog.
Illustrate the book as the children look on. Invite them to tell the story.
Ask children to be “illustrators” and draw pictures for their own books. Give help as needed. Use the same three words or have children suggest their own three words for their books.
Have children who wish to share, show their completed books to the group and tell their story.
Invite children to talk about the activity.
What is fun about being an illustrator?
How did your picture help to tell the story?

For children who are not quite ready to illustrate a particular word, you might read each word again for the child and ask them what to draw. Then you might begin the drawing and have the child complete it, perhaps by coloring or adding details.
Challenge the “illustrators” to add as many details as they can to their pictures. Use these prompts:
Does your picture show where the story takes place? What colors will you use to make the kite? What story does your picture show?

This is a wonderful activity for multilingual learners. You can add the word in their home language on the page, so they are making multilingual books! When they are finished you may ask them if you can add their multilingual books to the class library.

Children without fine motor skills may have difficulty drawing pictures. You can support those children by providing outlines (such as a diamond shape for a kite), or stickers to illustrate their scenes.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Paper, art supplies, a paper bag containing sticky notes labeled as follows:
library, post office, school, bakery, park, barber shop, pizza shop,
Today we talked about neighborhoods and read the map on the “Our Neighborhood”
We saw all different places in the neighborhood. Let’s see if we can name them—library, post office, school, bakery, park, barber shop, pizza shop, and market.
Now, let’s take turns choosing a place to draw.
You will take turns pulling a sticky note from the bag that names a place in the neighborhood. Then we’ll read the note together.
Next, you will draw a picture to show that place.

Have children take turns choosing a sticky note. Read the note together and talk about the place named. Then have children draw their pictures. Help them label the papers with the name of the place they are drawing.
After the pictures are completed, ask children to share their pictures with the group.
Set out the pictures and pretend to take a walk to all the neighborhood places, naming them as you go. At each place, you may want to stop and ask:
Why do people go there? What happens there?

Children may have difficulty making a drawing to match the word chosen from the bag. Help them by drawing an outline of a building and encourage them to fill in the details. Together, figure out what details to draw in the picture.
Challenge children to write a sentence that answers one of these questions:
Why do people go to that place in the neighborhood? What happens at that place in the neighborhood?
After children pull a name from the bag, help them read the note. Have them repeat the name. Then help them find the place on the map and name the place in their home language and in English.
Children with fine motor difficulties may not be able to grasp traditional supplies for drawing. You may want them to supply them with thick crayons and markers.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
